is the largest city in and capital of
There are direct flights Lisbon-Bissau with TAP
three times a week, all arrive currently at 01:10AM, returning the same day. Senegal Airlines also flies from Dakar

have four flights each week from Dakar to Bissau, returning to Dakar the same day. These flights are not an example of punctuality and it is a good idea to check with the TACV office in Bissau (Av. Amilcar Cabral 8B, tel. 206087) before you head to the airport.
A sept-place (7-seat shared taxi) from Ziguinchor, Senegal costs CFA$4,000.  Additional CFA$1,000 for a normal sized bag.  The trip takes 2.5 to 3 hours depending on border formalities..

Shared taxis are cheap and plentiful. Stop taxis and tell them where you want to go (or tell the passing taxis by pointing), and they will either accept "na bai" (I'm going), or decline "não" (no) if people, already in the taxi, are going to another part of the city. Prices are more or less fixed, and you'll normally not get cheated, except when you're an obvious foreigner and taking a taxi from the airport or Hotel Bissau Palace.

Group travel is cheaper, for example:

1 person 300 FCFA, 2 persons 300 FCFA, 3 or 4 persons 600 FCFA

There are also minibuses "toca-tocas" going on fixed routes, you'll pay 100 FCFA a person for the ride, but the buses are often very crowded!

value: content=Bombed-out during the civil war, but still standing, though now only inhabited by bats.
- the old Portuguese colonial centre. Not much life there nowadays, but still a nice place to walk around. Don't miss the
painted on its front (At the corner of the fort, close to the harbour).

- walk out the little port and talk to the fishermen, watch the pelicans and see the city from a distance. The Pidjiguiti port was the site of the Pidjiguiti massacre on 3 August 1959, where police shot down some 50 striking dockworkers. This became the beginning of the active resistance against the Portuguese colonial power. There is a monument shaped as a gigantic black fist commemorating the massacre.

- old Portuguese fort, containing the mausoleum of national hero Amilcar Cabral and tombs of other revolutionaries. Inside is also Amilcar Cabral's car. Can be hard to get in, but possible, if you make friends with the soldiers or get a permission.
directions=On the university campus, opposite "Lenox de Bairro"

content=Open mornings only, it has a small collection of Bissau-Guinean wooden masks and statues, baskets, cloths etc. The staff is very helpful and good at explaining the purpose of the different items, and connecting it to traditional spiritual beliefs.
in the Bayana roundabout often features concerts, movies, dance classes, French classes etc. Programme on their webpage
(next to the Portuguese embassy, behind "Benfica") also hosts concerts, but in slightly less inviting surroundings.
at Palace Hotel (5000 FCFA), Hotel Azalaï 24 de Setembro or Campo Sueco (3000 FCFA - somewhat more noisy and crowded, but more African atmosphere).
on the running lanes or in the gym in Estadio 24 de Setembro.
in the tennis club at the Bandim Harbour (close to Estadio 24 de Setembro) or in Campo Sueco.
Try the Centro Artistico Juvenil, close to "Chapa de Bissau" with fixed prices and no need to bargain - or the market in front of Pensão Central (here you'll need to bargain).
Good shop underneith Pensão Central selling textiles from NGO
in Quinhamel - or at the Bandim Market.

in Bairro de Belém is an NGO working for sustainable community development, food and income security as well as a greater control over the natural resources on which the local population is depending. It has a little shop selling high-quality wall-calendars and postcards with Guinea Bissau motives as well as locally produced baskets, marmalade, rice, spices, palm oil etc.
has a large selection of quality DVDs, that can be ordered from Portugal and picked up the following Friday.
has a good buffet every night at 20.00-7500 FCFA including starters, main courses, desserts, wine and water.
content=Probably the best restaurant in town. Has a swimming pool that non-guests can use for 5000 FCFA (eat lunch at the pool) - and wireless internet.
content=Has a nice restaurant inside, but also a roof top restaurant for drinks and fast food style meals.
- Belgian owned restaurant next to Mavegro, delicious food.
content=Good restaurant, and excellent service, but somewhat overpriced.

- Has an open air restaurant right on Praca Che Guevara (known as "Praca Bayana" by most cab drivers).  Excellent pizza and live music most nights, though relatively expensive (4000f - 5000f for a small pie).
Favorite place for pizzas and shawarmas. Very fair prices!
Restaurant of Hotel Kalliste in the Bayana roundabout, very tasty food and nice atmosphere.
open for lunch, has a nice courtyard for eating your morning croissants and espresso, or a good lunch.
very good for breakfast with croissants, pastries and sandwiches, coffee, natural juices etc. Located next to "meteorología".
good steak-restaurant next to the parliament, having a live gazelle and a crowned crane in the restaurant.
Chinese Restaurant uphill from the Bayana roundabout. It is a nice change, once you get tired of Portuguese and libanese style food.
in Santa Lucia - famous for her Bica (Carpe Rouge).
in Alto Bandim - good for lunch and a swim in the pool, while you wait for the food.
in Bissau Velho - nice place with outdoor serving in the street in the dry season.
- Fixed menu with soup, fish, meat and dessert for about 5000 FCFA for lunch or dinner
- same owner as "A Padeira Africana" - good for a beer and a snack on the sidewalk
- Moroccan restaurant close to Aparthotel Lobato, good fish, shawarma etc.
Popular local place with internet café, loud music, beer, shawarma, pizza, goats meat, sandwiches and other fast food.
Same concept, but without the loud music.
Libanese place for good sandwiches, shawarmas, burgers, pizzas, softice and wireless internet. No alcohol sold.
- libanese fast food and soft ice, no alcohol.
- next to Bayana roundabout. Food ok, Pizza good.
- Senegalese place above the closed cinema.
located in the very airport, it is fancy looking, but not good value for money.
on a sidestreet between Baiana and Benfica. Nice place with good and innovative Portuguese food, but the service varies quite a bit.
Restaurant of the ApartHotel Ruby, next to the UN building
- many Spanish brands, good value. One in the center, one in Estrada de Bor and one on the Airport Road, opposite Mercado de Bandim.
- tends to be somewhat expensiver than the others - with a big section of tableware, kitchen utensils, linen etc.
- Dutch supermarket, northern European food, wall-calendars and postcards from "Tiniguena", creole books and cartoons, historic books on Guinea Bissau.
- supermarket with a big section of shoes and clothes.
- opposite Dragon Chinese restaurant - is the best place in Bissau to buy cheese and frozen meat.

There are quite a few discos and nightclubs, one nightclub popular with expats is

.  The club has pool tables and a small dance floor.

Discos include Plack, Bambú, Sonhos, Orio etc.
Hotels in Bissau are generally overpriced. There's hope that prices will lower as new hotels are about to open.

value: content=This Pensão, is a good first stop, with clean rooms (shared toilets howewer) available at a 10000 CFA. It's conveniently located just a few meters away from the port
content=Run by a Swiss-Bissau couple, this hostal is good value

content=Situated in Bissau-Velho - all rooms with own bathroom, partly air-condition, ventilator, some rooms with freezer, all rooms with own veranda, best cost-performance ration in Bissau-Center, nice and typical guinean atmosphere - rooms from
content=Set in an old Portuguese colonial style building, that is repuditly under renovation. If that is not the case,  you'll be pleased to know that the interior is in a much better shape.
content=Former sheraton hotel that is now under Libyan management.
content=are currently undergoing renovation, so it might or might not be open
price=Singels CFA 50,000, doubles CFA 60,000, suites CFA 10,000 more
content=This hotel was renovated in 2009.  Has air conditioning, free breakfast and free wireless Internet (Wi-Fi).
price=Ask to see the room, bargain and expect 40,000 for a double
content=Clean hotel in quiet location. Friendly Lebanese owner. Prices include a simple French breakfast.
content=Fairly well maintained hotel, with rooms in better shape than the outside. On-site hotel and restaurant.
British Honorary Consul, Mavegro Int., CP100, Bissau

... But if you really need to go to the hospital, probably you should try and get your insurance company to pay for you at least going to Dakar.

Pharmacies are on every street corner in Bissau, pharmacies
are usually well-stocked and the Indian owners speak English.

- a nice get-away for a picnic if you're in Bissau on a longer term. Go to Porto Canoa (behind Mavegro and the cemetery) and ask around for a canoa to take you to the island, it takes about 10 minutes and you should not pay much for the return ticket (1000 FCFA?). Once there, check out the abandoned peanut oil factory, and continue through the little village down to a little "beach" (ask people where it is), from where you can turn left and walk along the coast, if you don't mind climbing a little over trees and rocks. For once there is no mangrove, so you can actually get the feeling of strolling along the coast.

Starting at the Porto Canoa, this track goes around Bissau, passing rice fields and small suburbs, the big cemetery in Antula, São Paulo etc., and eventually you'll end up at the airport road close to Hotel Bissau Palace. A nice Sunday walk, some 4 hours, not all stretches are suitable for vehicles.
, in Quinhamel. Makes a fine daytrip for swimming and lunch, and maybe a fishing trip. In the town of Quinhamel there's also an interesting weavery,  "Artissal"
is also recommendable, if you need to escape from Bissau for a day, swim and relax.

in Prabis is the Guineans favorite weekend get-away in the dry season. The beach is a bit muddy, but there's always good ambient with music, people dancing, barbecuing, playing football and swimming. Just follow Estrada de Bor out of Bissau, continue when it turns into a dirt road, and eventually you'll reach the beach (might be a two-hour drive).

- A pleasant little waterfall located just under the bridge where the main road to southern Guinea-Bissau crosses the Rio Corubal. There is a hotel "Pousada do Saltinho" overlooking the waterfalls, with decent rooms (FCFA 20.000) and meals. Many Portuguese hunters and fishermen stay there. About three hours drive from Bissau.
